Graphical abstract we report the preparation of a new N, P co-doped carbon supported material with atomically dispersed cobalt sites and its successful application in the oxidative amination and annulation of aryethylamines to access polysubstituted imidazoles. Further, the developed imidazoles showed excellent insecticidal activity against wheat pests. The development of reusable catalytic systems for achieving site-selective functionalization of C(sp3)-H bond remains a significant challenge. Herein, we designed a modified metal–organic framework (MOF)-derived N, P co-doped carbon supported single-atom cobalt catalyst, which was successfully applied in oxidative C(sp3)–H amination and cyclization of aryethylamines for construction of polysubstituted imidazoles. The advantages of the present method include: broad substrate scope, recyclable base metal catalyst, and naturally abundant O2 as green oxidant. The structural − activity relationship of the catalyst indicated that the atomically dispersed CoN3P1 is the active species responsible for the catalytic process. Furthermore, the synthesized imidazoles exhibited exceptional insecticidal activity against wheat pests, and may become lead molecules in the development of novel agricultural pesticide candidates, with significant application potential. Keywords Single-atom cobalt Amination Imidazoles MOFs Insecticidal activity Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The construction of C-N bonds serves as a powerful tool for obtaining N-heterocyclic compounds with potential bioactivity, which has been a hotspot in the field of organic synthesis research [1]. Traditionally, the most direct and effective way for building C-N bonds has been to use aryl or alkenyl halides to undergo cross-coupling reactions with nitrogen sources [2]. The transition metal-catalyzed C−H bond amination represents an alternative strategy, which directly activates the C–H bond without the need for pre-active substrate and has the advantages of higher step and atom economy (Scheme 1 A) [3]. Therefore, the direct amination of inert C–H bonds to construct nitrogen-containing heterocycles is gradually emerging as a novel synthetic strategy. Imidazole derivatives, as significant aromatic heterocyclic compounds, exhibit strong electron-withdrawing capabilities, planar coexistence, and facile chemical modifiability. These features grant imidazole derivatives a broad spectrum of pharmacological activities, such as anticancer, antitumor, antibacterial, and anti-inflammatory properties [4]. Furthermore, imidazole derivatives also serve as common pharmacophoric groups within the molecular structures of pesticides, demonstrating a wide range of fungicidal or insecticidal activities [5]. As a result, an increasing number of chemical researchers are dedicated to the synthesis and development of imidazole-based compounds [6]. Generally, these compounds are obtained by oxidative condensation of amines and carbonyl compounds or nitriles (Scheme 1B, path a) [7]. Other synthetic methods include: [3 + 2] cycloaddition of oxime acetates and vinyl azide or tetrahydroisoquinolines (Scheme 1B, path b) [8]; acid-catalyzed multi-component coupling reaction (Scheme 1B, path c) [9]; and intramolecular C–H amination/domino azidation of N-alkyl enamines (Scheme 1B, path d) [10]. Although these strategies are very effective, they still suffer from several shortcomings, such as: the requirement of stoichiometric oxidant; employing precious metal catalysts, which are difficult to separate and recycle; and the need to pre-functionalize the guiding groups or specific amination reagents. Hence, the development of free amines without protecting groups as amination reagents for the direct functionalization of C(sp3)-H bonds with reusable base metal catalyst would be of great importance. However, primary amines are inherently sensitive to electrophilic reagents and oxidants, and can easily coordinate with homogeneous transition metal complexes, leading to catalytic termination. Therefore, the construction of nitrogen heterocycles based on the direct amination reaction of free amines remains a significant challenge. Single-atom catalysts (SACs), characterized by their metal active sites anchored on the catalyst surface through metal-support interaction and evenly dispersed in atomic form, possess unique metal coordination structures and the highest atom utilization efficiency [11]. Furthermore, SACs have demonstrated exceptional catalytic activity in organic small molecule oxidation and reduction reactions, such as hydrosilylation, hydrogenation of olefins, and aromatic hydrocarbon oxidation [12]. SACs establish a bridge between heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts, combining the easy separation and recycling of the former, with the “isolated site” advantages of the latter. These properties can avoid the poisoning effect of the metal with amines, offering a promising new solution to the challenges faced in the direct amination of free amines to construct imidazole rings. Based on the unique catalytic performance of SACs, on the favorable anti-insect activity of imidazoles, and on our efforts towards the construction of nitrogen heterocycles using heterogeneous catalysts [13], we report the development of a metal–organic framework (MOF) derived N, P co-doped carbon-supported cobalt single-atom catalyst, and its application in the oxidative C(sp3)–H amination and cyclization of aryethylamines to obtain polysubstituted imidazoles (Scheme 1C). In the present work, C(sp3)–H bonds of amine were activated and three new C–N bonds were constructed in one step. Additionally, we evaluated the insecticidal activity of the synthesized imidazoles, aiming to provide lead compounds for the development of green pesticides. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Synthesis of Co-NPC/ZrO2 The N, P co-doped single-atom cobalt catalyst was prepared by pyrolysis of the surface functionalized MOF precursors [14]. As shown in Fig. 1 , the UiO-66-NH2 was first assembled in DMF via hydrothermal crystallization. Afterwards, the MOF UiO-66-NH2 surface was modified by functional grafted P ligand, which could provide a strong anchoring for subsequent cobalt metal coordination. Noteworthy, the interaction of Co precursor with N,P groups of UiO-66-NH2 inhibits the migration, aggregation, and leaching of cobalt. A final step was the direct pyrolysis and further acid etching of the above material, resulting in the formation of a Co single atom catalyst (denoted as Co-NPC/ZrO2). More details are provided in the Supporting Information. 2.2 Characterization of the Co-NPC/ZrO2 The pore properties of the catalyst were elucidated by using N2 adsorption − desorption measurements (Figure S1). A typical IV isotherm with hysteresis loop revealed the existence of hierarchically micro-, meso-, and macro-pores. The detected specific surface area was 871.19 m2g−1. Moreover, the distribution curve of the pore diameter revealed that the dominant mesopores were centered at 2–3 nm and 45 nm, while the regions at 57 − 82 nm corresponded to macro-pores. The highly specific surface and the hierarchical porous structure are expected to favor the rapid mass-transfer and exposure of sufficient active sites. The morphology and structural characteristics of the fabricated material was further investigated by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray (EDS) analyses. As depicted in Fig. 2 a–b, the catalyst maintained the basic octahedral morphology of UiO-66-NH2. High-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) (Fig. 2c) excluded the generation of large Co particles and aggregates. Moreover, the elemental mapping results (Fig. 2c–d) demonstrated a complete overlap between the signals of Co, N, P, Zr and C, indicative of strong coordination between the Co and N, P ligands. Finally, aberration corrected high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC HAADF-STEM) (Fig. 2e–f) further confirmed that Co atoms dominantly presented atomic dispersion on the N, P co-doped carbon and ZrO2 supports. X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) measurements were used to reveal the coordination environment and valence states of the cobalt catalyst. As shown in Fig. 3 a, the Co K-edge of the Co sample located between those of Co foil and Co3O4 in the red region, indicating that the elemental valence of Co was higher than that of metallic Co0 but lower than that of Co3O4 [15]. In the FT-EXAFS spectrum (Fig. 3b) and fitting results (Fig. 3c) of Co-NPC/ZrO2, two distinct peaks were observed at 1.52 Å and 1.9 Å, which could be ascribed to CoPc and CoP, respectively. No peaks could be attributed to the Co foil, excluding the possibility of direct Co-Co bonds. The average coordination number of Co − N and Co − P were ca.3.1 is ca.1.2, respectively, with mean bond lengths of 1.94 Å and 2.28 Å (Table S1). Moreover, in the second shell layer, two distinct peaks at 2.5 Å and 3.1 Å were dominated by Co-O-Zr or Co-O-Co coordination. The WT contour plots of Co-NPC/ZrO2 (Fig. 3d) and Co foil, Co3O4, CoPc, CoP (Figure S2a–d) showed a maximum near 4.5 Å−1, corresponding to Co–N bonding, while a maximum near 7.5 Å−1 associated with 9.5 Å−1, attributed to Co–P bonding [15]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted to investigate the surface compositions and the chemical valence states of the cobalt catalyst. The element contents on the surface were C (76.3 wt%), N (4.5 wt%), O (11.4 wt%), Zr (7.5 wt%), Co (0.15 wt%), and P (0.15 wt%). Furthermore, an ultralow Co loading was confirmed by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) (0.07 wt%). The broad peak in the N 1 s spectrum (Figure S2a) was deconvoluted into two peaks with Co–N (399.9 eV), graphitic-N (401.8 eV) [15]. The P 2p spectrum (Figure S2b) showed two small peaks at 133.3 and 134.5 eV, which were ascribed to P–C and P–Co bond, respectively [16]. Moreover, the Co 2p spectrum (Figure S2c) showed two characteristic peaks of Co3+ (779.2 eV) and Co2+ (782.9 ev), which are ascribed to Co–N and Co–P bonds with single Co atoms [16]. 2.3 Catalytic performance After clarification of the structure–activity relationship of the catalyst, we aimed at verifying the oxidative amination and annulation reaction. Initially, we selected the homo-coupling of phenethylamine 1a as a model to evaluate the reaction parameters. Notably, imidazole 3a was successfully obtained from the condensation of tri-molecular phenethylamine with 18 % yield under the synergistic catalysis of heterogeneous cobalt and acid (Table 1 , entry 1). However, no product was formed in the absence of catalyst or acid (entries 2–3), indicating that both are essential to the reaction. A series of acidic additives (entries 4–9) were subsequently screened, which indicated that Yb(OTf)3 was the best choice. Various types of catalysts, including cobalt precursors and related heterogeneous cobalt catalysts (entries 10–14), were also screened. The results showed that the single-atom Co-NPC/ZrO2 exhibited the highest activity. Moreover, different calcination temperatures of Co-NPC/ZrO2 showed that 800 °C performed the best activity (entry 15). The catalyst Co-NC/ZrO2 without P doping led to a decrease in yield (entry 16), suggesting that N, P co-doping favors the catalyst activity. Other polar or less-polar solvents were less effective than DMSO (entry 17). The temperature screenings (entries 18–19) showed that the highest product yield (81 %) was obtained with a temperature of 100 °C. Finally, increasing the amount of catalyst was not fruitful for the yield (entry 20). The use of catalyst that was not etched with HF led to a rapid decline in yield (entry 21). Taking all of the above into consideration, the optimal conditions were as described in entry 18. The next step was to examine the substrate scope of the new synthetic protocol when performed under the optimal conditions described above. Initially, the self-coupling of various aryethylamines 1 (1a − 1u, with substrate structures depicted in Scheme S1) was conducted. As shown in Scheme 2 , all the reactions proceeded smoothly and gave rise to the desired polysubstituted imidazoles in moderate to high yields upon isolation (3a-3u). A range of functional groups (–Me, –OMe, −naphthyl, −Ph, –F, –Cl, –Br, –CF3, –OCF3) were well tolerated. Specifically, phenethylamines with electron-donating groups corresponded to relatively higher product yields(3b-3f) when compared with electron-withdrawing ones (3o-3 t). This phenomenon is attributed to the the fact that electron-rich substituents enhance the –NH2 nucleophilicity, thus favoring the condensation process. The steric effect on the aryl ring of substrates 1 affected product formation just slightly (3b-3d). Furthermore, the structure of product 3 l was identified by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Notably, heteroaromatic amine 1u proved to be an effective coupling partner, affording the product 3u in 31 % yield. Disappointedly, the more challenge aliphatic amine n-Butylamine 1v was not applicable with our catalyst system (3v). The next step was to verify the substrate suitability for cross-coupling of different aryethylamines. According to the available literature [17], arylethylamines may be converted to diketones under oxidizing conditions, and are likely to be important intermediates for the method developed herein. Hence, we tested the ability of the reaction of 2-oxo-2-phenylacetaldehyde 2a with various aryethylamines 1 to yield unsymmetrical imidazoles. As shown in scheme 3 , the condensation reaction of 2a and 2 molecules of 1 successfully yielded the corresponding imidazole compounds under the same catalytic system (3da-3ua). These examples suggested that the 1,2-diketone compounds may serve as intermediates in the reaction. To check whether the newly developed catalyst has the potential to be reused, we performed the model reaction 7 consecutive times and analysed the product yield after each repeat. As shown in Fig. 4 , the catalytic activity was well retained, albeit with a slight decrease in product yield after seven cycles, which demonstrated the high durability and stability of the catalyst. The slight decline in catalytic activity was ascribed to the loss or partial aggregation of active cobalt species, which originated from mechanical abrasion-induced exfoliation during the continuous cyclic process. To verify the utility of the synthetic products, several representative imidazoles and three common insecticides were tested for insecticidal activity. As shown in Table S2, most of the compounds exhibited weak insecticidal activity against Rhopalosiphum padi. Interestingly, the compounds 3o, 3k and 3q displayed high insecticidal activity against R. padi. At 24 h after treatment, the LC50 values of 3o and 3k were 2.074 and 2.035 mg/L, respectively, which is lower than those of imidacloprid (15.240 mg/L), lambda-cyhalothrin (4.836 mg/L) and chlorpyrifos (3.904 mg/L) (Table 2 ). In addition, the mortality rate of R. padi treated with different concentrations of compounds 3o, 3k and 3q was dose-dependent (Fig. 5 ). Similar results were observed at 48 and 72 h post-treatment. Notably, the presence of the different substituents on the imidazole derivatives had a major impact on the insecticidal activity. For example, at 24 h post-treatment, unsubstituted 3a at 8 mg/L only caused 5.6 ± 2.2 % mortality, whereas 3o and 3 k at the same concentration caused 62.2 ± 2.9 % and 65.6 ± 4.0 % mortality, respectively. These results suggested that the derivatives 3o, 3k and 3q may serve as attractive lead molecules for the discovery of new pesticides with potent efficacy. To figure out the possible reaction mechanism, several control experiments were performed (Scheme 4 ). Firstly, the model reaction was terminated after 2 h to analyze the possible intermediate. We detected the desired product 3a with a yield of 18 %, whereas N-phenethyl-1-phenylmethanimine 1A and N-phenethylbenzamide 1B were corresponded to 5 % and 3 % yield, respectively (eq. a). However, extending the model reaction time to 16 h did not significantly alter the yield of 1A or 1B. Moreover, the reactions of either 1A or 1B with 2-(p-tolyl)ethan-1-amine 1d were unable to yield cross-coupling product 3da (eq. b), excluding the possibility that 1A or 1B may serve as intermediates. On the other hand, the reaction of 1d with either phenylacetaldehyde 1a’or 1,2-diketone 2a produce the desired unsymmetrical imidazole 3da with 35 % (eq. c) or 45 % yield (eq. d), respectively. These results indicate that 1a’ and 2a may be intermediates. The moderate yield of 3da may be due to the occurrence of homo-coupling reactions of substrate 1d. Treating 1a with N, P co-doped material without metallic cobalt produced 3a with a yield of 29 % (eq. e). Finally, the poisoning experiment [18] was performed to further identify the active components of the catalyst. The addition of KSCN to the model reaction led to a significant decrease of catalyst efficiency(eq. f). These results indicate that single-atom CoN3P1 acts as an active species in the catalytic reaction, which is consistent with the results of the XAFS analyses. On the basis of the findings reported above, and in agreement with previous reports [7d,17], a plausible reaction pathway for the formation of 3 is depicted in Scheme 5 . Firstly, arylacetaldehyde 1′ is generated in situ via the oxidative deamination of aryethylamines 1, with the assitance of the Co/O2 system. Then the active α-site of 1′ undergoes a second oxidation, which gives rise to the 1,2-diketone compound 2. The condensation of two molecules of 1 and 2 forms intermediate I, which undergoes oxidation and intramolecular nucleophilic annulation to yield intermediate III in the synergistic catalysis of cobalt and acid. Finally, the proton elimination of III affords the desired product 3. 3 Conclusions In summary, by employing a MOF surface functionalization strategy, we have developed N, P co-doped carbon supported cobalt catalyst with atomic dispersion, which was applied in the first oxidative amination and annulation of easily available aryethylamines to poly-substituted imidazoles. During this transformation, two types of sp3 C–H were cleaved and new C-N bonds were constructed in one pot. The catalyst structure − activity relationship revealed that the single-atom site CoN3P1 served as catalytic species. The catalyst could be easily separated and recycled up to seven times, while still maintaining high reactivity. Furthermore, the synthesized imidazoles showed high insecticidal activity against one of the most severe wheat pests. The current work describes an important application of single-atom catalysts in the synthesis of organic small molecules, and provides potential lead molecules for the development of novel pesticides. coredata.dc:description: The development of reusable catalytic systems for achieving site-selective functionalization of C(sp3)-H bond remains a significant challenge. Herein, we designed a modified metal–organic framework (MOF)-derived N, P co-doped carbon supported single-atom cobalt catalyst, which was successfully applied in oxidative C(sp3)–H amination and cyclization of aryethylamines for construction of polysubstituted imidazoles. The advantages of the present method include: broad substrate scope, recyclable base metal catalyst, and naturally abundant O2 as green oxidant. The structural − activity relationship of the catalyst indicated that the atomically dispersed CoN3P1 is the active species responsible for the catalytic process. Furthermore, the synthesized imidazoles exhibited exceptional insecticidal activity against wheat pests, and may become lead molecules in the development of novel agricultural pesticide candidates, with significant application potential.

coredata.dc:title: Direct construction of imidazoles via oxidative C(sp3)–H amination and annulation of aryethylamines by a Single-Atom cobalt catalyst
